javadoc: ArrayStringable identifies those data types which when formed into an array can be interpreted as a string (e.g., character array). The {@link Array} implementations will leverage this interface as both a marker and to generate appropriate representations and values for data instances.

methods.name: hasStringValue
methods.comment:
For cases where an array of this type exists, determines if a String value
 will be returned.

return.comment:
true if array of this type with the specified settings will return
 a String value.

methods.name: getArrayString
methods.comment:
For cases where an array of this type exists, get the array value as a String.
 When data corresponds to character data it should generally be expressed as a string.
 A null value is returned if not supported or memory is uninitialized.

return.comment: array value expressed as a string or null if data is not character data

methods.name: getArrayDefaultLabelPrefix
methods.comment:
For cases where an array of this type exists, get the appropriate string to use as the
 default label prefix for the array.

params.name: options
params.comment: options for how to format the default label prefix.

return.comment: the default label prefix or null if none specified.

methods.name: getArrayDefaultOffcutLabelPrefix
methods.comment:
For cases where an array of this type exists, get the appropriate string to use as the
 default label prefix, taking into account the fact that there exists a reference to the
 data that references offcutLength bytes into this type

params.name: options
params.comment: options for how to format the default label prefix.

return.comment: the default label prefix or null if none specified.

methods.name: getArrayStringable
methods.comment:
Get the ArrayStringable for a specified data type. Not used on an Array DataType, but
 on Array's element's type.

name: ArrayStringable
comment:
ArrayStringable identifies those data types which when formed into
 an array can be interpreted as a string (e.g., character array).  The Array
 implementations will leverage this interface as both a marker and to generate appropriate
 representations and values for data instances.
